chunks.text: Welcome to web development with React. React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces, particularly single-page applications.
React uses a component-based architecture. Components are reusable pieces of UI that can have their own state and props.
JSX is a syntax extension that allows you to write HTML-like code in JavaScript. It makes React components more readable and intuitive.
State management is crucial in React. The useState hook allows functional components to have local state.
Props are used to pass data from parent to child components. They are read-only and help maintain unidirectional data flow.
The useEffect hook handles side effects in functional components, such as data fetching, subscriptions, or DOM manipulation.
React Router enables client-side routing in single-page applications. It allows navigation without full page reloads.
Component lifecycle methods in class components, or hooks in functional components, let you run code at specific times.
Context API provides a way to share data between components without prop drilling through every level.
Performance optimization techniques include React.memo, useMemo, and useCallback to prevent unnecessary re-renders.
Building forms in React requires controlled components where form data is handled by React state.
Testing React applications can be done with Jest and React Testing Library for unit and integration tests.
Deployment options include Vercel, Netlify, or traditional web servers. Build optimization is important for production.
This introduction covered React fundamentals. Continue learning by building projects and exploring the React ecosystem.
